events.summary: The US National Security Strategy (NSS) document was released, outlining a shift in foreign policy under the Trump administration. The document, primarily authored by Michael Anton, emphasizes concerns over European immigration, suggesting it could lead to "civilizational erasure." It also revives the Monroe Doctrine and reduces the US's role in great power competition with China and Russia. The NSS has been criticized for its radical stance, particularly its Euroscepticism, which has been described as "official doctrine" by European leaders. The document reflects the administration's focus on immigration as a national security priority.
events.title: Release of the US National Security Strategy Document

traits.trait_name: National history is rewritten to glorify conquest, not justice

events.summary: Following the arrest of an Afghan man suspected of shooting two national guard soldiers, the Trump administration has frozen asylum decisions at the US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) and paused visa and immigration applications filed by Afghans. Additionally, the administration has halted all legal immigration cases for nationals of 19 countries listed on its travel ban, including citizenship ceremonies. These actions have created uncertainty for thousands of Afghan immigrants and asylum-seekers in the United States, affecting their ability to secure legal status and work permits.

events.summary: On December 12, 2025, House Speaker Mike Johnson unveiled a Republican healthcare plan that does not extend the enhanced tax credits for Americans purchasing insurance through the Affordable Care Act (ACA) marketplaces. These credits, set to expire at the end of the year, currently help lower premiums for those not covered by employer insurance. The Republican proposal focuses on expanding access to employer-sponsored plans and regulating pharmacy benefit managers but omits the tax credit extension, potentially increasing premiums for millions. The plan is set for consideration in the House next week.
events.title: House Republicans propose healthcare plan without extending ACA tax credits
events.why_relevant: The proposal could significantly impact healthcare affordability for millions of Americans, affecting access to necessary medical services.

events.summary: On December 18, 2025, Donald Trump signed an executive order reclassifying marijuana from a Schedule I to a Schedule III controlled substance. This change aims to facilitate marijuana-related medical research and reduce regulatory burdens on legal cannabis businesses. The order also initiates a pilot program to reimburse Medicare patients for CBD products and directs the Department of Health and Human Services to develop research methods for studying the long-term health effects of medical marijuana. The reclassification does not legalize marijuana federally and requires the DEA's formal rule-making process.

events.summary: President Trump announced $1,776 "warrior dividend" checks for service members, presenting them as a personal gesture of support. However, the funds were reallocated from congressionally allocated housing allowances, effectively repurposing money intended to help troops afford housing. This move has been criticized as misleading and detrimental to service members facing a housing crisis.
events.title: Trump Announces "Warrior Dividend" Checks from Housing Allowances
events.why_relevant: The reallocation of military housing funds for political gain undermines trust and support for service members.

events.summary: In December 2024, ABC settled a defamation lawsuit with President Trump by agreeing to contribute $15 million to his presidential library and pay $1 million in legal fees. The lawsuit stemmed from an incorrect statement by anchor George Stephanopoulos regarding Trump's liability in a case involving E. Jean Carroll. Despite legal experts considering Trump's case weak, the settlement was reached. This settlement is part of a broader pattern of media concessions to Trump, raising concerns about media independence and influence. events.summary: President Trump signed an executive order classifying illicit fentanyl as a "weapon of mass destruction" (WMD). This designation typically applies to chemical and biological threats, not narcotics, and allows the administration to employ a national-security approach to drug enforcement. The order reframes the issue as a wartime escalation, potentially expanding the legal and political tools available for enforcement. The White House released a fact sheet detailing the administration's directives to federal agencies in response to this new classification.
events.title: Fentanyl Designated as "Weapon of Mass Destruction"

events.summary: The Trump administration's Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed changes to formaldehyde exposure standards, reversing Biden-era findings that any level of exposure to the chemical poses a cancer risk. The proposed changes would increase the levels of formaldehyde considered safe, potentially maintaining industry profits while reducing public health protections. The proposal is part of a broader effort to weaken risk assessments around toxic chemicals, with the EPA now led by former industry executives. The changes have been criticized for undermining scientific consensus and public health.
events.title: Trump’s EPA Proposes Weakened Formaldehyde Protections

traits.trait_name: Administrative agencies are deregulated or captured by private interests

events.why_relevant: This proposal could significantly impact public health by allowing higher levels of a known carcinogen in consumer products, reflecting a shift in regulatory priorities under the Trump administration.

events.summary: Thirty members of the US Congress have sent a letter to the CEOs of Dollar General and Family Dollar, demanding internal documents regarding price disparities between shelf and register prices at their stores. This action follows a Guardian investigation revealing widespread pricing errors at these chains. The letter, authored by Representative Nikki Budzinski and signed by 29 other Democrats, questions the companies' commitment to affordability and consumer transparency. It also criticizes the companies' use of forced arbitration agreements, which limit customers' legal recourse. The lawmakers seek four years of correspondence on pricing practices and revenue from inaccuracies.
events.title: Congress members demand answers on price disparities at dollar-store chains
events.why_relevant: This congressional inquiry highlights concerns about consumer protection and corporate accountability, impacting public trust and economic fairness.

events.summary: On December 19, 2025, the U.S. Department of Justice released a heavily redacted set of files related to Jeffrey Epstein, failing to comply with the Epstein Files Transparency Act, which mandates the release of all related documents within 30 days of the law's enactment. The partial release has prompted criticism from lawmakers, including Representatives Robert Garcia and Jamie Raskin, who are considering legal action against the DOJ for violating federal law. The law allows withholding only for personal information of victims or materials that could impede ongoing investigations or national security.
events.title: DOJ Releases Partial Epstein Files, Violating New Law

events.summary: A federal document, revealed in a court filing by immigration attorneys, shows that US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) is pressuring unaccompanied children to return to their countries of origin. This document was filed in a Washington DC court as part of a lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) by the National Immigrant Justice Center (NIJC) and other organizations. The advisal has been criticized for being coercive and misleading, exploiting the vulnerabilities of unaccompanied children.

events.summary: The U.S. Department of Justice released a heavily redacted cache of documents related to Jeffrey Epstein, including FBI notes detailing his demands for procuring underage girls. events.summary: Wisconsin judge Hannah Dugan was found guilty of obstruction by a jury in Milwaukee. She was accused of helping a Mexican immigrant evade arrest by federal immigration authorities at her courthouse. The jury acquitted her on a related charge of concealing an individual to prevent arrest. Dugan faces up to five years in prison and is expected to appeal. Her case has drawn attention due to its connection to the Trump administration's immigration policies. Dugan was suspended from her judicial position following the charges, and Wisconsin Republicans have threatened impeachment if she does not resign.
events.title: Wisconsin Judge Found Guilty of Obstruction
events.why_relevant: The conviction of a judge for obstruction in the context of immigration enforcement highlights tensions between judicial authority and federal immigration policies.

events.summary: The FBI has initiated "criminal and domestic terrorism investigations" into threats against immigration enforcement activities in at least 23 regions across the United States. These investigations are linked to a memo issued by Donald Trump in September, known as NSPM-7, which calls for a national strategy to counter violent and terroristic activities associated with anti-fascism. The FBI's internal report, dated November 14, highlights increased threat activity targeting government personnel or facilities related to immigration enforcement efforts. Civil rights groups have expressed concerns that these investigations could be used to suppress leftist organizing and dissent.
events.title: FBI opens domestic terrorism investigations into anti-ICE activity
